title: Question 10
prompt: Which of the following actions would stop Lake Chapala from disappearing?
description:
Click the one best answer to each question.

The largest lake in Mexico, Lake Chapala, is becoming smaller. Lakes naturally fluctuate in size because of seasonal rainfall and climate cycles, but Lake Chapala has been shrinking since the late 1970s. Less water comes into the lake because increased farming upstream removes water from rivers before it reaches the lake. Nearby Guadalajara, the second largest urban area in Mexico, has also been increasingly using water from Lake Chapala for the city’s residents and industry. The lake is an important resource for the local tourism economy and as a home for many species of birds and fish.
feedback:
The passage states that farming, local residents, and industry all use water from the lake’s system, making it shrink. Managing the water use so that the lake does not lose more water than it can replenish, or refill, would stop the lake from shrinking.
